thread.title: Wetherspoon's pubs are getting rid of drinks from the European Union

author: Oliver Astley
title: Wetherspoon's pubs are getting rid of drinks from the European Union
text:
Wetherspoon's pubs are getting rid of drinks from the European Union No more Champagne for Wetherspoon's punters Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get Daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Drinks such as Champagne and prosecco could soon be a thing of the past at Wetherspoon's pubs as the chain prepares to get rid of booze imported from the European Union.
As well as continental wines, fewer lagers from Belgium, Germany and Holland will be available as the pub chain prepares for Brexit.
The changes will start to come into effect at all of Wetherspoon's 880 outlets from July 9, reports Wales Online .
Its idea is to sell more drinks from the UK and non-EU nations.
Leicester city centre's Wetherspoon pubs are The High Cross Pub, Highcross, The Last Plantagenet, in Granby Street, and Lloyds No.1 at the Corn Exchange.
Sparkling wines from the UK and Australia will replace Champagne and prosecco while wheat beers produced in France and Germany will lose out to those produced in the UK. The Last Plantagenet in Granby Street
Wetherspoon chairman Tim Martin, a strong supporter of Brexit, said: "This move helps us to broaden our horizons so that we create an improved offer for the two million customers who visit our pubs each week.
"It is the start of a review all products in the next six to 24 months, with the object of making our business more competitive. Read More 13 enchanting National Trust days out within an hour's drive of Leicester
"The EU's customs union is a protectionist system which is widely misunderstood."
He went on: "It imposes tariffs on the 93% of the world that is not in the EU, keeping prices high for UK consumers.
"Tariffs are imposed on wine from Australia, New Zealand and the US, and also on coffee, oranges, rice and more than 12,000 other products.
"There will be an inevitable transfer of trade post-Brexit to countries outside the EU, which will reduce prices in shops and pubs. Read More
"The products we are now introducing are at lower prices than the EU products they are replacing.
"We intend to honour existing contracts with EU suppliers, some of which have several years to run.
"However, we are starting to make the transition to non-EU trade now." Like us on Facebook
